message:
Hi there,

Thanks for this great post.  
Have I correctly understood, then, that if your current code has been triggered by Task.Run() (or even TP.QUWI, if your code is /very/ old school) then the Context is NOT one of these awkward blocking ones ... it's a ThreadPool context and thus it's fine to call await without .ConfigureAwait(false), and then to block on the result of that call.

I've currently got some multi-threaded code that is Task.Running a bunch of threads, each of which currently calls WebRequest.GetResponse() and synchronously waits on the result, and the initiating thread is calling WaitAll on the collection of Tasks that it ran.

I believe I can convert to await GetResponseAsync, bubbling async through the methods until it hits the initiating thread, at which point I leave the WaitAll untouched. And I can do all this without needing to use ConfigureAwait(false) and also without triggering a Deadlock.

Have I got that right?
